content:
• Monday, September 30, 2013

  • Tankan survey beats expectations as Abe readies tax hike

    • Japan Tankan large manufacturing index: 12 versus 7 expected and 4 in the quarter through June.
    • The print was the highest reading since December of 2007.
    • This is welcome news for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe as he prepares to raise the sales tax to 8% from 5% — upbeat economic news reinforces the idea that the Japanese economy can withstand the tax hike.
    • Japan August household spending: -1.6% versus +0.1% expected.
    • Nikkei +1%, yen -0.39% to ¥98.59.
    • ETFs: EWJ, NKY, EWV, EZJ, ITF, JSC, JPP, DXJ, SCJ, DFJ, FJP, JPNL, JPNS, DXJS, JGBT, JGBL, JGBS, JGBD
     
     
     
     
    | 10:32 PM | 1 Comment
  • HCI

    HCI Group to replace Maidenform in S&P SmallCap 600

    • Property and casualty insurer HCI Group (NYSE:HCI) will replace Maidenform Brands (NYSE:MFB) in the S&P SmallCap 600 after the close of trading Oct. 4; Hanesbrands is acquiring MFB in a deal expected to be completed on or about that date.
    • HCI +2.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:42 PM | 1 Comment

  • After-Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top Gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: TWI +7%. AMPE +6%. GERN +4%. FOXF +3%. NFJ +3%.
    • Top Losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: PFMT -9%. DMND -5%. UEC -4%. AEPI -3%. DSL -3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:40 PM
  • DMND

    Diamond Foods reverses AH on FQ1 outlook

    • After being up 4% AH on a FQ4 beat (juiced by a one-time $13M tax benefit), Diamond Foods (NASDAQ:DMND) shares have reversed and are down 5.9% after management said on the conference call that it expects "significant sales and contribution headwinds" in FQ1 due to the relaunch of its Emerald line and lower walnut supply.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:06 PM | 1 Comment
  • MYGN

    Myriad Genetics suffers late sell-off

    • Myriad Genetics (NASDAQ:MYGN) tumbled nearly 10% just before the close.
    • Chatter indicates Noridian is pricing BRCA testing at $1500, down from $2795.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:27 PM | 6 Comments
  • BGCP

    BGC Partners guides towards low-end of range

    • The company expects Q3 results to be towards the low-end of previously stated guidance - revenue of $410M-$440M and pre-tax earnings of $36M-$46M.
    • BGCP -2.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM
  • DMND

    Diamond Foods beats by $0.12, beats on revenues

    • Diamond Foods (NASDAQ:DMND): FQ4 EPS of $0.09 beats by $0.12.
    • Revenue of $199.8M (-10.8% Y/Y) beats by $7.27M. Shares +3.99% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:10 PM

  • Corn slides to 3-year low after bearish stocks data

    • Corn (CORN -2.4%) and Soybeans (SOYB -3.2%) tumble - with corn hitting a 3-year low - after the USDA reports estimated corn stocks of 824M bushels, off 17% from a year ago, but far higher than trade estimates for 687M. Bean stocks are estimated at 141M bushels, also off 17% from a year ago, but 13% above estimates. Stocks still remain low, but these are old crop numbers, and forecasters are looking forward to a big crop this fall.
    • Wheat (WEAT -2.7%) stocks of 1.85B bushels were slightly below expectations.
    • Lower-than-expected feed usage and export demand were behind the big corn number - high prices had pig farmers substituting corn for wheat.
    • Relevant grain ETFs: JJA, RJA, AGF, DBA, FUD, UAG, DAG, AGA, ADZ, JJS, TAGS, USAG, RGRA, JJG, GRU.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:49 PM | 2 Comments
  • UUU

    Seeking Alpha moves stocks

    • Universal Security (UUU +7.2%) has its second big session in a row following the Friday publishing of SA Pro's Saj Karsan's bullish article. The shares have tumbled over the last six weeks on heavy volume - but with no insider sales and no news. It suggests to Karsan an attempt by an outside investor to quickly raise cash. By Karsan's calculation, the stock is trading at more than a 60% discount to book value.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:34 PM
  • CNIT-OLD

    China Information Technology plunges on 3M share equity incentive grant

    • Shares of China Information Technology (CNIT-OLD -17%) are plunging after the company disclosed that it had granted 3M restricted shares to employees as part of its 2013 equity incentive program at a price of $3.00 per share with a 13-month lock-up. (6-K)
    • The shares represent a dilution of 11.1%.
    • Today's move also smacks of momentum reversal, after shares climbed 32% last week.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:46 PM
  • ARQL

    ArQule slides as tivantinib rally disappears

    • As expected, ArQule (ARQL -7.4%) presented MARQUEE data over the weekend at ECC and thanks (at least in part) to RBC's Adnan Butt and Reuters, investors had high hopes that new information would lead to a second chance for tivantinib in NSCLC. (see original Reuters article)
    • Judging by today's market reaction, investors were underwhelmed (or just taking profits after Friday's rally).
    • MARQUEE was halted last fall after it became apparent that the study was unlikely to meet the OS primary endpoint.
    • However, the data presented over the weekend appears to show a PFS benefit (secondary endpoint): "In the ITT population of 1048 patients ... median PFS was 3.6 months in the treatment arm versus 1.9 months in the control arm."
    • Hazard ratio was 0.74 compared to 0.98 for OS. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:46 PM
  • TOT

    Total sells E&P assets in Trinidad & Tobago for $473M

    • Total (TOT -1.6%) sells all its exploration and production assets in Trinidad and Tobago for the country's state-run National Gas Company for $473M.
    • TOT says the sale is in line with its strategy of simplifying the portfolio by divesting non-strategic assets in countries where the production outlook is marginal, but it will maintain a presence in the country through the distribution of oil products.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:39 PM
  • ECYT

    Chardan bullish on vintafolide as Endocyte slides

    • Chardan Capital starts Endocyte (ECYT -3.7%) at Buy with a $20 price target on the familiar "vintafolide/ etarfolatide alone are worth around $6/share" thesis.
    • "We expect ... positive data from the ongoing Phase 3 trial in folate receptor -positive ovarian cancer and in a randomized Phase 2 trial in FR (100%) NSCLC to drive significant upside," analyst Ling Wang says.
    • Investors have been reluctant to jump in however, with the stock off some 28% since hitting a 52-week high at the beginning of August.
    • For more, see SA contributor Benjamin Paluch's recent article.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • BP

    BP unprepared, misled officials on Gulf spill, plaintiffs lawyers say

    • Long before the 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, BP (BP -1.9%) knew its Macondo well could explode and then lied about how much oil leaked, lawyers for plaintiffs seeking damages allege at today's opening of the second phase of the civil trial.
    • BP's staff had not been trained in responding to a deepwater blowout, or even conducted a drill, and were “left to make things up on the fly as oil gushed into the gulf," plaintiffs lawyer Brian Barr says.
    • In response, a lawyer for BP tells the U.S. District Court that the company followed U.S. spill preparation standards; "that's not fraud, that's not gross negligence."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM | 1 Comment
  • CYTR

    Aegis likes CytRx on aldoxorubicin PFS potential

    • Aegis wants investors to focus on ORR and not stable disease when evaluating the potential of CytRx's (CYTR -2.4%) aldoxorubicin.
    • "While the percentages of patients exhibiting stable disease at this stage appeared comparable between the aldoxorubicin and doxorubicin treatment arms, we note that there was a 22% partial response rate in the aldoxorubicin group vs. 0% in the doxorubicin group," analyst Raghuram Selvaraju notes, adding that Aegis "believes [the] study has a high likelihood to demonstrate a PFS signal in favor of aldoxorubicin when the interim analysis results ... are released later this year."
    • Buy rating and $7 price target maintained.
    • See also: CYTR gives aldoxorubicin update.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:51 PM
  • RJETQ

    Frontier sale at risk for Republic Airways

    • Shares of Republic Airways (RJET -4.1%) trade lower as a deadline approaches for the sale of Frontier Airline with labor unrest still in the background.
    • A Teamsters union repping Frontier pilots continues to make a lot of noise over the group's demands.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:51 PM
  • ANGI

    Angie's List drops on news of CTO departure

    • Angie's List's (ANGI -3.1%) discloses Manu Thapar, the company's CTO since Oct. 2011, is no longer working for the company, and that his "responsibilities have been assumed by other members of the company's senior engineering team."
    • The disclosure's wording suggests Thapar, who had senior engineering positions at MySpace, Yahoo, and Cisco before joining Angie's List, might not have left on his own volition.
    • Last month, Angie's List hired Nokia exec Thomas Fox to be its CFO, ending a 5-month search.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:44 PM | 8 Comments
  • REGN

    The Street gets bullish on Regeneron following Eylea DME data

    • Regeneron (REGN +2.7%) enjoys some bullish commentary out of the sell-side following the presentation of Phase 3 Eylea data in DME at the Retina Society's annual meeting. (full presentation)
    • "The data clearly supports label expansion with blockbuster potential even competing with approved Lucentis (OTCQX:RHHBY, NVS) and off-label Avastin," Piper's Edward Tenthoff says, before going on record with predictions of $56M and $177M in sales in H2 2014 and FY15 for the new indication, respectively. Price target raised to $360 from $336.
    • Goldman is out with similar comments, saying the VIVID/VISTA data "were in line with ... expectations and [should] support approval for a broader label and drive uptake/growth.” Price target raised to $355 from $329.
    • Also: Oppenheimer's David Ferreiro lifts his target to $310 from $300.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:40 PM
  • OGXPY

    OGX Petroleo continues plunge on default, bankruptcy speculation

    • Shares of OGX Petroleo (OTCPK:OGXPY -18.6%) fall further as investors fear the end is near. OGX's $2.56B in debt due 2018 has tumbled to 15 cents on the dollar - Bloomberg reports that the company is set to miss a $45M interest payment due tomorrow, citing 2 sources.
    • Sao Paulo magazine Veja reported over the weekend that OGX will file for bankruptcy protection in 2 weeks time as the oil producer's burn rate puts it on the brink of running out of cash to continue operations.
    • In a last ditch effort, OGX hopes to receive $250M in new capital from investors in a plan to restructure $3.6B in debt so that it can extend operations long enough to start pumping oil at Tubarao Martelo.
    • Shares have collapsed 99% since the beginning of 2012.
     
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM
  • UL

    Unilever warning has broader implications

    • A warning from Unilever (UL -2.5%) on profits in emerging markets is creating some selling pressure on rivals.
    • Procter & Gamble (PG -1.5%) and Church & Dwight (CHD -1.6%) are both lower with the EM currency warning from Unilever resonating in the background.
    • Related ETFs: XLP, VDC, IYK.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:29 PM

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Top 10 Gainers: DLHC +26%. ACTV +26%. CNR +25%. CSUN +24%. OTC:AMCF +21%. AXDX +19%. LDK +16%. MY +15%. RCON +15%. OTC:ZAZA +15%.
    • Top 10 Losers: ACHN -59%. ICEL -15%. CNIT-OLD -14%. PME -14%. CACG -14%. ARNA -11%. HMPR -10%. CTC -10%. FLWS -9%. OIBR -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:50 PM
  • PBR

    Petrobras gains on speculation of Brazilian fuel price increase

    • Petrobras (PBR +1.8%) bucks today's broader downtrend after CEO Maria das Gracas Foster expresses optimism for an increase in Brazilian fuel prices.
    • PBR is planning a new price adjustment policy to stem losses from fuel imports, Brazilian newspaper O Globo reported yesterday, citing an interview with Foster, who said that she is working for it to happen.
    • “Investors are optimistic that the long-awaited increase is very close,” says the top analyst at the SLW Corretora brokerage firm.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM | 1 Comment
  • UL

    Unilever warns of emerging market slowdown

    • Weakening growth in emerging markets should bring overall underlying sales growth to 3-3.5% in Q3, says Unilever (UL -2.4%). Significant weakening in domestic currencies is the culprit behind the EM slowdown, according to the company. Developed market growth remains flat to down.
    • "We continue to grow ahead of our markets and expect underlying sales growth to improve in Q4 ... we are still on course to deliver against our priorities of profitable volume growth ahead of our markets, steady and sustainable core operating margin improvement, and strong cash flow."
     
     
     
     
    | 12:28 PM | 3 Comments
  • WTI

    W&T Offshore ups capex budget, acquires interest in Dantzler project

    • W&T Offshore (WTI -2.4%) raises its 2013 capital budget to $550M for increased deepwater activity, completion costs on successful exploration wells and additional onshore drilling at the Yellow Rose Field.
    • As part of increased deepwater activity, WTI acquires a 20% working interest in the Dantzler prospect in the Gulf of Mexico, operated by Noble Energy (NBL -0.5%), which has estimated a prospect resource potential of 50M-220M boe.
    • WTI says the increased budget doesn't include potential acquisitions.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM
  • ZAZA

    ZaZa Energy gets deal for further development of Eaglebine/Eagle Ford

    • ZaZa Energy (OTC:ZAZA +14.8%) shares are strong after announcing a second transaction with its unnamed joint venture partner to acquire additional production and further develop its Eaglebine/Eagle Ford assets.
    • As consideration for the Phase II election, ZaZa will receive $17M plus interests in 15 of its partner's wells with a PDP present value of $3M based on an independent reserves report.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:47 AM
  • STP

    Chinese solar stocks rally (again) following gov. tax rebate plan

    • The Chinese government, which has already set a 35GW 2015 solar installation target, is now offering local solar manufacturers a 50% value-added tax (VAT) rebate for sales taking place from Oct. 2013-Dec. 2015.
    • Chinese solar plays are responding well to the news. STP +15.6%. CSUN +23.5%. LDK +13.4%. SOL +5.4%. DQ +4.5%. JASO +3.9%. TSL +4.1%. YGE +3%.
    • Also: JinkoSolar (JKS +3.6%) has announced a deal to supply 20MW of modules to the State Grid Corporation (China's biggest electric utility) for a 60MW demonstration project. Deliveries will take place in Q4.
    • Last week's gains: Wednesday, Thursday, Friday
     
     
     
     
    | 11:44 AM
  • CLVS

    Clovis weak after AstraZeneca presents early-stage NSCLC data

    • Clovis Oncology (CLVS -4.2%) adds to Friday's losses and is now down some 20% since last Tuesday, when Bloomberg reported that the company had found no takers after hiring Credit Suisse to pursue a sale.
    • CLVS said Sunday at the ECC that its PARP inhibitor rucaparib is showing promise in a Phase 1 ovarian cancer study. The company says it has seen "significant clinical activity with one complete response in breast cancer and six partial responses in ovarian, breast and pancreatic cancers to date, and a disease control rate in patients with germline BRCA mutant ovarian (platinum-sensitive and platinum-resistant) cancer of 100% and 63% at 12 and 24 weeks, respectively." (PR)
    • As we tipped Friday however, preliminary results from a Phase 1 study of AstraZeneca's (AZN +0.7%) AZD9291 may be weighing on CLVS shares, as AZN's treatment for NSCLC patients with the T790M mutation is a competitor for CLVS' CO-1686.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM
  • MLNX

    Mellanox rallies reportedly thanks to bullish analyst comments

    • A bullish sell-side note predicting Mellanox (MLNX +5.9%) will meet or beat Q3 estimates is giving a lift to the beaten-down InfiniBand adapter card/switch/IC vendor.
    • Mellanox has been pressured this year by bad earnings news and concerns about the 2014 arrival of Intel Xeon CPUs (based on its next-gen Broadwell architecture) with built-in I/O connectivity. Shares -36% YTD.
    • The stock has been a favorite of institutional short-sellers. 12.5% of the float was shorted as of Sep. 13.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:14 AM | 1 Comment
  • AMCX

    AMC Networks breaks higher after hit show concludes

    • AMC Networks (AMCX +1.2%) trades higher on a weak market day after Barron's taps the stock to see more gains even with hit series Breaking Bad now wrapped up.
    • Ratings aren't in yet for last night's final episode of the AMC show, but the feedback on the show remains a Google trending topic today and has lit up Twitter.
    • On tap for AMC: The network still has another season for Mad Men, perhaps a few more for The Walking Dead, and is going to take a shot at a Breaking Bad spinoff with Better Call Saul.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • HLF

    Teflon: Herbalife shrugs off city councilman's FTC letter

    • It's almost as if shares of Herbalife (HLF +3.8%) relish any opportunity to rally in the face of negative press.
    • The stock is surging on the last day of the quarter, even as a letter from Boston City Councilor Tito Jackson to the FTC surfaces.
    • "I urge you to [conduct a] thorough investigation into HLF's sales and marketing practices to ensure my constituents and the residents of Boston are protected,” Jackson says in the letter, after noting that he has received complaints alleging the company preys "on disadvantaged populations ... offering them 'income and hope,’ [and instead delivers] ... 'debt and despair.’"
    • Despite the controversy, the stock continues to bedevil shorts and is up nearly 17% in September alone.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:57 AM | 8 Comments

  • Southeast Asian shares tumble amid foreign selling

    • Indonesian shares (EIDO, IDX, IDXJ) are hit with more foreign selling (~$70B), helping to send the JCI 2.4% lower in Jakarta.
    • Also stumbling are stocks in Thailand (THD, TF, TTF), the Philippines (EPHE), and Singapore (EWS, EWSS), where shares are off 2.4%, 3%, and 1.3% respectively.
    • Vietnamese stocks (VNM) buck the weak regional trend, rising 1.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:39 AM
  • ACHN

    Achillion collapses after Friday's AH rout

    • Needless to say, Achillion Pharmaceuticals (ACHN -55%) is having a rough day.
    • The stock has lost over half its market value after Friday's pipeline "update."
    • Downgrades are out from Piper, William Blair, JMP, and BofA.
    • SA contributor Stephen Simpson calls the stock "burnt toast."
     
     
     
     
    | 10:32 AM
  • FREEF

    Dry bulk shippers lower as capesize rates slide

    • Dry bulk shippers are smacked following a sharp decline in capesize shipping rates for a third consecutive day.
    • Overnight, capesize rates fell 4.2% (or $1,598/day) to $36,425/day and have dropped 14% (or $5,786/day) in the last three days; panamax rates fell 0.3% (or $48) to $14,388/day, while supramax rates rose 0.9% (or $100) to $11,279/day.
    • The Dry Bulk Index fell 2.1% (or 43 points) to 2,003 overnight, but has doubled since Aug. 12, led by capesize rates which have climbed 245%, largely driven by higher iron ore shipments to China out of Brazil and Australia (Briefing.com).
    • Earlier: Wells Fargo cautious on recent dry bulk rally.
    • FREE -7.2%, DRYS -5.5%, SBLK -4.8%, EGLE -4.3%, SHIP -3.8%, BALT -3.1%, DCIX -2.6%, DSX -2.7%, GNK -2.6%, SB -2%, PRGN -1.2%, SINO -0.8%, VLCCF -0.5%, KEX -0.1%.
    • ETF: SEA.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:24 AM
  • SLS

    Galena Biopharma jumps amid Abstral, NeuVax anticipation

    • Galena Biopharma (GALE +8.4%) is enjoying a strong session.
    • Possibly helping the cause are several generally bullish articles published over the weekend by SA contributors Stock Whisper, Dutch Trader, and Fusion Research.
    • While optimism surrounding Abstral and NeuVax is running high, investors weren't pleased with the company's recent offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:22 AM | 1 Comment
  • ARNA

    Credit Suisse sinks Arena with bearish note

    • A downbeat note out of Credit Suisse hits shares of Arena Pharmaceuticals (ARNA -6.6%) hard in early trading.
    • CS slashes Belviq estimates for Q4, FY14, and FY15 to $12M (from $36M), $157M, and $325M, noting that although "these are substantial cuts ... getting to [the] new numbers will still require exponential growth [and] will require Eisai (OTCPK:ESALF) to hire additional reps."
    • Other (decisively bearish) takeaways: Profitability is now forecast for 2017 (versus 2016 previously), "slower ramp results in lower royalties and also defers the timing of milestone payments," the company "may need to do another round of financing next year."
    • Price target cut to $4 from $5.
    • Also lower: VVUS
     
     
     
     
    | 10:11 AM | 3 Comments
  • DDD

    3D printing stocks underperform following bearish Blair note

    • William Blair, which has been bearish on 3D printer makers for a while, is out with another critical note on 3D Systems (DDD -2.7%). The firm expects thinks sales growth is slowing, and reports sales stemming from 3D's Staples partnership have been dismal.
    • Stratasys (SSYS -1.6%) and ExOne (XONE -2.7%) are following 3D Systems lower on a rough morning for equities.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:41 AM | 4 Comments
  • NVS

    Ariad trades lower after AP26113 news despite Oppenheimer upgrade

    • AP26113 is "a much stronger contender than Novartis' (NVS -0.3%) LDK378, given the cleaner safety profile, and [we] anticipate meaningful uptake in the crizotinib-refractory setting," Oppenheimer's David Ferreiro says, referring to Ariad's (ARIA -3.6%) tyrosine kinase inhibitor and its prospects in ALK+ non-small cell lung cancer.
    • Ferreiro is also upbeat on Iclusig in CML, saying he believes the drug "will acheive significant adoption in the first-line setting, despite Gleevec genericization."
    • ARIA upgraded to Outperform from Perform, although the target is raised just $1 to $24 — remember, Ferreiro thinks positive AP26113 data is already factored into the stock's price.
    • Nevertheless, the stock is weak at the open. It's possible investors are reacting negatively to the following line in the company's ESMO PR: "In three out of 26 patients receiving 180 mg per day of AP26113 in the Phase 2 portion of the trial, early-onset pulmonary symptoms were observed after the first dose of AP26113."
     
     
     
     
    | 9:36 AM | 1 Comment
  • BB

    A roundup of tech ratings changes

    • BlackBerry (BBRY) has been upgrade to Market Perform by Bernstein. Shares nonetheless -1.4%, following equity futures lower.
    • Accenture (NYSE:ACN) has been upgraded to Hold by SocGen. Shares sold off on Friday in response to the company's soft FQ1/FY14 guidance.
    • Xilinx (NASDAQ:XLNX) has been upgraded to Outperform by Pac Crest. Shares -0.6%.
    • Telecom Italia (NYSE:TI) has been upgraded to Neutral by JPMorgan following reports CEO Franco Bernabe is set to resign, a move that could clear the way for Latin American asset sales. Shares +3.1%.
    • RealPage (NASDAQ:RP) has been cut to Underperform by Credit Suisse. Shares -3.5%.
    • Chinese online gaming firm NetEase (NASDAQ:NTES) and Giant Interactive (NYSE:GA) have been started at Buy by BNP Paribas.
    • Marketo (NASDAQ:MKTO) has been started at Outperform by Wells Fargo.
    • CyrusOne (NASDAQ:CONE) has been started at Overweight by Evercore.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:26 AM

  • Premarket Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: ACTV +26%. BPO +17%. CNTF +9%. HNR +6%.
    • Losers: ACHN -52%. FU -6%. GERN -5%. DRYS -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:14 AM
  • GME

    GameStop readies itself for critical holiday season

    • GameStop (NYSE:GME) says it will hire 17K seasonal employees to meet an unexpected rush of store traffic following the launch of the Xbox One and PlayStation 4.
    • Every holiday season is important to the company's financial health, but this year's level of consumer demand will be an important gauge to where the retailer's business model stands.
    • GME -1.1% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:08 AM
  • SHPG

    Shire upgraded at JPMorgan, shares tick higher

    • JPMorgan upgrades Shire (NASDAQ:SHPG) to Overweight.
    • Price target hiked to $142 from $106.
    • SHPG +1.3% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:53 AM
  • BGMD

    CMS revises payment rate for BG Medicine's Galectin-3 test

    • BG Medicine (OTC:BGMD) soars 22% premarket as the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services sets the Medicare payment rate for BGM Galectin-3 at $30.24.
    • For 2013, the test's limitation amount was $17.80.
    • CEO Paul Sohmer is understandably "very pleased." (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:50 AM
  • BPY

    Brookfield Property offers $19.34 per share for Brookfield Office

    • Brookfield Property Partners (NYSE:BPY) offers to buy what it doesn't already own of Brookfield Office Properties (NYSE:BPO) for $19.34 per share. BPO shareholders can accept either cash or shares of BPY (which closed Friday at $19.34) for their stake. The total value of the deal is about $5B.
    • Trying to sell the deal to Brookfield Office shareholders, BPY notes they're getting a premium of 17% to the 30-day average share price. Those who accept stock in BPY will be getting a 79% increase in dividends and an 18% increase in book value.
    • Easy game: SA Pro's Mike Arnold made a particularly well-timed bullish call on Brookfield Office just last Thursday.
    • BPO +15.2% premarket to $19.32.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:29 AM
  • RIO

    Rio Tinto coal mine draws three bids but all disappoint

    • Rio Tinto (NYSE:RIO) has received three bids for its majority stake in the Clermont mine in Australia's Queensland state, but all three fell short of expectations, WSJ reports.
    • Rio is cutting costs and seeking to sell assets including coal stakes in Australia and Mozambique and an iron ore mine in Canada, but coal assets have been hard to sell due to easing demand from China, which has resulted in a slump in coal prices.
    • Clermont is one of Rio's newest and largest coal operations; it was opened in 2010 and will supply up to 165M tons of thermal coal in its expected 16-year lifetime.
    • RIO -2.7% premarket, as mining firms are under pressure after economic data from China came in weaker than expected: VALE -2.2%, BHP -1.4%, FCX -0.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:28 AM | 1 Comment
  • JCP

    J.C. Penney weak again in early trade

    • Shares of J.C. Penney (NYSE:JCP) aren't firming up a bottom quite yet as the reverberations of the retailer's common stock offering are still being felt.
    • JCP -3.0% premarket to $8.76.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:20 AM
  • ACRX

    AcelRx Pharmaceuticals jumps on Zalviso NDA

    • AcelRx Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ACRX) submits an NDA for Zalviso (sub-Q sufentanil).
    • The company hopes the drug will supplant at least some usage of IV-delivered opioids in the hospital setting.
    • Because ACRX doesn't qualify as a "small business," the company did have to pay $1.95M to file the NDA. The fee will be on the Q3 income statement.
    • ACRX +4.7% premarket.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:10 AM
  • HNR

    Harvest Natural +7% on news of talks to sell interest in Gabon

    • Harvest Natural Resources (NYSE:HNR) +7.2% premarket on news it is in exclusive talks to sell its stake in in the Dussafu Marine Permit offshore Gabon to energy trader Vitol for $137M.
    • Earlier this month, HNR said that it was in talks to sell its Venezuelan assets to Pluspetrol Venezuela for $373M; if it could reach an agreement and complete the sale, it said it planned to spin off its non-Venezuelan assets, including stakes in Gabon, Indonesia, Colombia and China to HNR shareholders.

    Active Network to be acquired for $14.50 per share

    • Active Network (NYSE:ACTV) agrees to be acquired by Vista Equity Partners for $14.50 per share in cash, or about $1.05B.

  • Chinese shares buck global trend

    • While global shares fall, Chinese stocks end +0.7% to cap their best quarter in three years despite HSBC PMI data proving to be weaker than first thought.
    • Companies with Shanghai in their names did especially well following the opening of the city's Free Trade Zone yesterday.
    • Chinese markets will be closed for a week from tomorrow.

  • U.S., Italian political turmoil sends shares tumbling

    • Equities are lower in most places around the world as the U.S. government heads for a shutdown at midnight tonight and Italy's government faces collapse.
    • However, European shares remain near five-year highs and are on course for their best quarter in two years.

  • Italian markets in turmoil as PM tries to save government

    • Italian shares plunge 2.25% in early trading, while ten-year bond yields climb 8 bps to 4.65% following Silvio Berlusconi's decision over the weekend to withdraw his support for the ruling coalition and pull five ministers out of the cabinet.
    • Prime Minister Enrico Letta is set to request a parliamentary vote of confidence for Wednesday as he looks to save his government and avert new elections. One possible hope is that disaffected members of Berlusconi's People of Liberty will back Letta.
    • The crisis comes as the former PM faces a vote over whether he should be expelled from the Senate following his conviction for fraud.
    • ETFs - Stocks: EWI. Bonds: ITLT, ITLY
